item.title: Foreign Monitors Enter Ukraine to Observe Political Situation
item.description: Deployment of the first observers was seen by some as the first break in the crisis over Crimea since Russia annexed it last week.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: U.N. Report Faults Syria and Rebels for Blocking Relief Supplies
item.description: The document is likely to spur fierce arguments among the members of the deeply divided Security Council, but it is unlikely to result in any immediate enforcement measures.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Syrians on Sunday inspected a damaged neighborhood in Aleppo, which activists said was the target of a government airstrike.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Economic Pressure on Kiev
item.description: Russia and Russian state companies have increased the economic pressure on the new pro-Western government in Kiev, closing the border to most trucks, shutting a Ukrainian factory in Russia and yet again raising the price of natural gas.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A Russian military ship near Sevastopol on the Crimean Peninsula, where Moscow’s Black Sea naval fleet is stationed.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Taiwan President Calls on Students to End Occupation of Legislature
item.description: President Ma Ying-jeou called the students’ occupation illegal and reinforced his intention to follow through with a trade pact with China they are protesting.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Breaking With the West, Afghan Leader Supports Russia’s Annexation of Crimea
item.description: Afghanistan’s president cites “the free will of the Crimean people,” in a statement issued shortly after he met with three members of the United States Congress.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Japan to Let U.S. Assume Control of Nuclear Cache
item.description: Japan will announce Monday that it will turn over to Washington more than 700 pounds of weapons-grade plutonium and a large quantity of highly enriched uranium.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Far Right Party Stirs Municipal Elections in France
item.description: The far right National Front party was poised to make a strong showing in the first round of French municipal elections held on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Dispute on Sri Lanka War Crimes Escalates
item.description: An conflict between the United States and Sri Lanka is expected to rise to another level this week.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and DHARISHA BASTIANS
item.media:description: Government supporters marched to the American Embassy in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital.

item.title: Adolfo Suárez Dies at 81; Led Spain Back to Democracy
item.description: Mr. Suárez, who helped fill a power vacuum left by the death of Gen. Francisco Franco in 1975, was a key figure in the country’s transition back to democracy.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Adolfo Suárez, center, with his successors Felipe Gonzalez, right, and Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo in 1998.

item.title: News Analysis: 3 Presidents and a Riddle Named Putin
item.description: He has argued with United States presidents, lectured them, misled them, accused them, kept them waiting, kept them guessing, betrayed them and felt betrayed by them.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in the Kremlin on Friday, where he signed legislation completing the annexation of Crimea. He has rebuffed overtures from the West since taking office.

item.title: Obama and Allies Seek Firm, United Response As Russia Grips Crimea
item.description: As Russia consolidated its hold on Crimea, President Obama and several allies prepared to meet in The Hague in an effort to develop a strong response despite their diverging interests.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR, ALISON SMALE and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Russian troops firing into the air and backed by armored vehicles stormed a Ukrainian airbase in Crimea on Saturday.

item.title: Kigali Journal: Rwanda Reaches for New Economic Model
item.description: A country is looking to attract investors, not donors, to transform a tiny rural economy into a financial and high-tech hub for the region.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Anger Grows in Taiwan Against Deal With China
item.description: The demonstrators fear President Ma Ying-jeou and the Kuomintang reached a trade agreement that will give Beijing too much influence over the island’s economy.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: A Pay Strike in Israel Stalls Premier’s Trip to Mexico
item.description: Foreign Ministry employees announced a general strike over pay and working conditions, shutting down the ministry’s work in Israel and 103 diplomatic missions abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Standoff Over Prisoner Release Threatens Mideast Talks
item.description: Though all parties have an interest in extending peace negotiations, the politics surrounding Israel’s impending release of a fourth batch of Palestinian prisoners may be too much to overcome.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat
item.description: As the United States made a public case about the dangers of buying from Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, classified documents show that the National Security Agency was creating its own back doors — directly into Huawei’s networks.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Adolfo Suárez Dies at 81; First Elected Spanish Prime Minister After Franco
item.description: Mr. Suárez, who helped fill a power vacuum left by the death of Gen. Francisco Franco in 1975, was a key figure in the country’s transition back to democracy.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Manuel Hernandez de Leon/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Adolfo Suárez, left, then the Spanish prime minister, went to the aid of Manuel Gutiérrez Mellado, the deputy prime minister, during a coup attempt in the Spanish Parliament on February 23, 1981.

item.title: U.S. Intelligence Officials Believe Snowden Is Working With Russia, Lawmaker Says
item.description: Representative Mike Rogers’s assertions about the former National Security Agency contractor expanded on his previous suggestions, for which he has yet to offer evidence.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Turkey Downs Warplane From Syria After Warning
item.description: Two planes entered Turkish airspace Sunday, but one turned back to Syria after a Turkish warning. When the other plane did not comply, a Turkish jet shot it down, a military statement said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: More Possible Sightings In Hunt for Missing Plane
item.description: Chinese and French satellites spotted possible debris as the search for the missing Malaysian flight, now in its third week, continued on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Turkish Jets Down Syrian Warplane Near Border
item.description: Turkish fighter jets shot down a Syrian warplane Sunday after it violated the country's airspace, Turkey's prime minister said, in a move likely to ramp up tensions between two countries already deeply at odds over Syria's civil war.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Bird Strike Shatters Malaysia Jet’s Windshields
item.description: As efforts to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 continued, a plane landing in Nepal collided with a flock of ducks.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Countries Divided on Future of Ancient Buddhas
item.description: Thirteen years after the Bamian Buddhas were blasted into rubble, opinion is split on whether to leave them as is, rebuild them, or make copies of them.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy walked his donkeys past a niche where a Buddha once stood in Bamian, Afghanistan.

item.title: No Bail for Former I.R.A. Member Charged in ’72 Killing
item.description: Ivor Bell, 77, is accused in the abduction and murder of Jean McConville, a mother of 10 who had been accused of spying for the British Army.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: U.S. Emerges as Central Stage in Asian Rivalry
item.description: Experts say that both Japan and South Korea have the same goal: cajoling Washington into pressuring the other to make concessions in their bitter rivalry over history and geography.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Korean-American groups persuaded the city of Glendale, Calif., near Los Angeles, to build a bronze statue of a “comfort woman.”
